description: From Latin sēgregātus, perfect passive participle of sēgregō (“I separate”), from sē- (“apart”) + gregō (“I flock or group”), from grex (“flock”). Compare gregarious, aggregate.

adjectives.description: segregate (comparative more segregate, superlative most segregate)

entries.meaning: (botany) Separated from others of the same kind.
(geology) Separate from a mass and collected together along lines of fraction.

verbs.description: segregate (third-person singular simple present segregates, present participle segregating, simple past and past participle segregated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To separate, especially by social policies that directly or indirectly keep races or ethnic groups apart.
examples: Throw me in cuffs, no chance of parole / Back in the house, thirty days in the hole / Segregate me from the local population, your love is, uh, incarceration
